summary: George de Mohrenschildt was a figure of interest in the JFK assassination context due to his connection with Lee Harvey Oswald. Documents reveal his association with Oswald, as well as connections to individuals such as Willem Oltmans, Jean K. Saurel, and H. Charles. Oltmans' connections to Cuban and Soviet diplomats and his testimony before the House of Representatives Assassinations Committee regarding de Mohrenschildt's link to Oswald are noted. De Mohrenschildt's name appears in connection with CIA memos and reports, including information about Jean K. Saurel and observations at the National Airport in Washington. The documents suggest that de Mohrenschildt's relationships and activities were of interest to both the CIA and Congressional committees investigating the assassination.
significance: George de Mohrenschildt's significance in the JFK context stems from his association with Lee Harvey Oswald. His connections and activities were of interest to the CIA and Congressional committees investigating the assassination, suggesting a potential link or knowledge related to the events surrounding JFK's death.
